step.context: \textbf{Check Point\#1: }\text{Is the following function}\\ \text{defined and continuous in }\left[0 , \dfrac{\pi}{4}\right]?
step.tex: \text{Yes. }\tan x\text{ is defined and continuous in }\left[0,\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right]
\text{No. }\tan x\text{ is not continuous at }x =\dfrac{\pi}{2}\text{ and}\\ \text{therefore not defined and continuous in }\left[0,\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right]
step.reason: \text{It is important to check for continuity in the}\\ \text{interval because it only makes sense if the}\\ \text{function is defined and continuous in the interval.}\\ \text{for example }\int_{\dfrac{\pi}{4}}^{\dfrac{3\pi}{4}}\tan x.dx \text{ is not defined because}\\ \text{at }x =\dfrac{\pi}{2}\in \left[\dfrac{\pi}{4}, \dfrac{3\pi}{4}\right] \tan x\text{ is discontinuous.}

\begin{align} A = \int_{0}^{\dfrac{\pi}{4}}\tan x.dx &= \int_{0}^{\dfrac{\pi}{4}}\underbrace{\dfrac{\sin x}{\cos x}}_{\text{Put }t =\cos x}.dx\\ &=\int_{0}^{\dfrac{\pi}{4}} -\log \left|\cos x\right|.dx\\ &= -\log \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} + \underbrace{\log 1}_{ = 0}\\ &=\underbrace{\log \sqrt{2}}_{ - \log \,\frac{1}{N} = \log N}\\ &= \dfrac{1}{2}\log 2 \end{align}
